title: 107_s156
content: The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 2001" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and decrease the risk of youth becoming victims of crime by providing productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face greater social risks, spend more time unsupervised, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are more severe in 2001. After school programs have proven beneficial in many states. After school programs are effective in addressing social issues like drugs, alcohol, and gang involvement among youth. Many governors support increasing these programs through a Federal/State partnership. Leading police chiefs and prosecutors advocate for after school programs to be provided by public officials. Public officials are urged to provide after school programs for school-age children and teens in the United States, offering recreation, academic support, and community service experience to ensure safe and positive learning environments during after school hours. The Act aims to increase academic success, promote safe after-school environments, provide alternatives to negative activities, and reduce juvenile crime. It amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to increase program authorization from 3 to 5. Section 10904 of the Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include various stakeholders in the program and require recipients to provide a minimum of 35% of the annual cost from sources other than government funds. The recipient must contribute a minimum of 35% of the annual project cost from non-government sources, which can be in cash or in kind. Additionally, no more than 25% of the project's annual cost can come from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs. The recipient must also maintain their fiscal effort each year of the project. The recipient must contribute 35% of the project cost from non-government sources, with no more than 25% from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs. They must also maintain their fiscal effort each year. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers that provide various activities, including job skills preparation and after school programs with specific requirements. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act allows grants for establishing or expanding centers that offer mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additional activities may include drug, alcohol, and gang prevention, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation. At least 2/3 of the funds appropriated each fiscal year must be used for after school programs. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act allocates funds for after school programs, including activities that provide expanded opportunities for children and youth. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include provisions for local educational agencies, schools, or consortia to involve volunteers from various communities, ensure youth participation in designing after-school activities, and use creative outreach methods. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to involve volunteers, ensure youth participation in designing activities, request donations of equipment, and collaborate with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 9. Amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to include law enforcement organizations in the definition of community learning centers. SEC. 10. Increases authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2002-2006 to carry out the Act. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2001.
